occurrences.line_text: And equall armes himselfe did forward set.
As fast as forward erst, now backward to retrate.
They tooke their steeds, and forward thence did pas
Yet saw her forward still to make her flight,
Would flit a litle forward, and then stay,
So forth they yode, and forward softly paced,
Th'one forward looking, th'other backeward bent,
Whom he requir'd his forward hast to stay,
We on his first aduenture may him forward send.
They pressed forward, entraunce to haue made.
Yet stayd she not for them, but forward fared,
Then taking leaue of them, she forward went,
Who seeing her approch gan forward set,
But on his first aduenture forward forth did ride.
And forward marched to a towne in sight.
To find him out, yet still I forward trace.
Would thumpe her forward, and inforce to goe,
When forward we should fare, he flat refused
She on her way cast forward to proceede,
Eftsoones they pricked forth with forward pryde,
Then vp he made him rise, and forward fare,
So as they forward on their way did pas,
Him hardly forward drew, whereas the thiefe
Did him, they say, forwarne through sacred spell.
Had not that charme from thee forwarned it:
Forwasted all their land, and them expeld:
And their forwasted kingdome to repaire:
Forwasted all, till Genuissa gent
Ye all forwearied be: for what so strong,
For-wearied with my sports, I did alight
Ye both forwearied be: therefore a whyle
His nigh forwearied feeble feet did slide,
That he with worke may be forwearied.
And foure, since Florimell the Court for-went,
Whiles vnawares his saddle he forwent,
That their well knowen courses they forwent,
A silly man, in simple weedes forworne,
And foster father of the Gyant dead;
Be to thy foster Childe, that from thy hand
Lo where a griesly Foster forth did rush,
But after the foule foster Timias did striue.
Of my deare foster child, to ease thy griefe,
She left, pursewing that same foster strong;
After that wicked foster fiercely went.
Her selfe freed from that foster insolent,
A foule ill fauoured foster, I haue seene;
After that foster fowle he fiercely rid,
But that fierce foster, which late fled away,
And still the foster with his long bore-speare
Which fled so fast from that same foster stearne,
To stint all strife, and foster friendly peace,
And with them carried, to be fostered;
Was fostered by those Graces, (as they say)
three fosters Timias wound,
Long fostred in the filth of Lerna lake,
Long time she fostred vp, till he became
And fostred vp with bitter milke of tine,
Which she with her long fostred in that wood,
I trust a liue, sith I thee fostred first;
Where he was fostred long in Stygian fen,
She should it cause be fostred vnder straunge attyre.
He lightly left the foe, with whom he fought,
(Said he) and battailes none are to be fought?
And many bloudie battailes fought in place
And many battailes fought, and many fraies
Already fought, his voyage to pursew.
He fought great battels with his saluage fone;
An army brought, and with him battell fought,
Fought with Seuerus, and him ouerthrew;
And eke those six, which lately with her fought,
And cruell battels, which he whilome fought
That oft for her in bloudie armes they fought.
Yet from thenceforth more warily he fought,
But euer vanquisht all, with whom he fought;
So long they fought, that all the grassie flore
A Champion, that had with his Champion fought,
That same is it, which fought for you this day.
Fought many battels without wound or losse;
Slayne of that errant knight, with whom he fought;
Fell all at ods, and fought through fury fierce and bold.
Long since had fought in field. Als Claribell
How they within their fouldings close enwrapped bee.
Did rend the ratling skyes with flames of fouldring heat.
Foule Errour doth defeate:
Till that infernall feend with foule vprore
To wish you backe returne with foule disgrace,
Most lothsom, filthie, foule, and full of vile disdaine.
For to all knighthood it is foule disgrace,
Her fawning loue with foule disdainefull spight
There lies he now with foule dishonour dead,
And with foule vgly forme did her disgrace:
A filthy foule old woman I did vew,
But they did seeme more foule and hideous,
With foule reproches, and disdainfull spight
With balefull beggerie, or foule disgrace,
And in a foule blacke pitchie mantle clad,
With wounding words and termes of foule repriefe
With foule enfouldred smoake and flashing fire,
Faire Ladie, through foule sorrow ill bedight,
Death were too little paine for such a foule despight.
How that same knight should do so foule amis,
And now is fled; foule shame him follow, where he went.
From foule intemperance he oft did stay,
That many errant knights hath foule fordonne:
Purged from drugs of foule intemperance:
He wist not whether blot of foule offence
That mote him honour win, to wreake so foule despight.
She gins her feathers foule disfigured
But turning said to Trompart, What foule blot
In foule reproch, and termes of vile despight,
Her bitter rayling and foule reuilement,
Engrost with mud, which did them foule agrise,
The whiles my soule was soyld with foule iniquitie.
Against foule feends to aide vs millitant?
That sire he foule bespake, Thou dotard vile,
And with foule cowardize his carkasse shame,
For knighthoods loue, do not so foule a deed,
First praise of knighthood is, foule outrage to deface.
With foule repulse from Fraunce was forced to retire.
Him his nobilitie so foule deface;
Delights in filth and foule incontinence:
For to reuenge that foule reprochfull shame,
But after the foule foster Timias did striue.
Then must he her forgoe with foule defame,
That none of them foule mischiefe could eschew,
Late foule dishonour and reprochfull spight,
Least that it should her turne to foule repriefe,
Of whose foule outrage they impatient,
So deepe the deadly feare of that foule swaine
Night thou foule Mother of annoyance sad,
Foule horror, and eke hellish dreriment:
A foule ill fauoured foster, I haue seene;
And his foule sore reduced to faire plight:
Whereof conceiuing shame and foule disgrace,
His falsehood, and with foule infamous blot
In that foule plight a comely personage,
And many hath to foule confusion brought.
But he was foule, ill fauoured, and grim,
So sore, and with foule outrages opprest:
And foule aduantage this good Knight dismayd,
Whose Lord hath done my loue this foule despight?
Colour thy name with foule reproaches rust.
Yet Blandamour with termes of foule despight,
Through that false witch, and that foule aged dreuill,
On whom I waite to wreake that foule despight,
And eke defiled with foule villanie
From foule mischance; ne did it euer rest,
A foule and lothsome creature did appeare;
A foule and loathly creature sure in sight,
Then faire grew foule, and foule grew faire in sight,
Then faire grew foule, and foule grew faire in sight,
From such foule outrage, and them long forbore:
And eke the loue of Ladies foule defame;
Besides ten thousand monsters foule abhor'd
Into all filth and foule iniquitie,
The faire Irena with his foule misdeede,
The trembling foule dismayd with dreadfull sight
From that foule monster, which did her compell
Voide of malitious mind, or foule offence.
And foule blaspheme that Queene for forged guyle,
But that she it with foule abuse did marre;
And many other crimes of foule defame
Euen foule Adulterie her face before,
And foule Echidna, in the house of night;
Sayd Artegall; What foule disgrace is this,
With so foule blame, as breach of faith once plight,
Most foule and filthie were, their garments yet
That her mis-shape much helpt; and her foule heare
Her hands were foule and durtie, neuer washt
And of her owne foule entrayles makes her meat;
And foule abusion both his honour blent,
The which shal nought to you but foule dishonor yearne.
But to release his former foule condition.
Standing alone on foot, in foule array:
Tooke in foule scorne, that I such fault did find,
But forst to trot on foot, and foule misused,
I may auenge him of so foule despight.
With wrathfull fury for so foule a shame,
To that foule feend, who dayly doth attend
In sad misfortunes foule deformity,
Ne euer shewed signe of foule disloyalty.
The foule discourt'sies and vnknightly parts,
Begot of foule Echidna, as in bookes is taught.
Wrought to Sir Calidore so foule despight;
And foule defame doe decke thy bloudy baner?
To shew such faintnesse and foule cowardize,
Foule womanwronger, for he him defyde.
The warie foule his bill doth backward wring;
How fortuneth this foule vncomely plight,
Were vanquished, and put to foule disgrace,
To whom foule Infamie, and fell Despight
Met her in such misseeming foule array;
Yond Lady and her Squire with foule despight
Who now does follow the foule Blatant Beast,
Blew vp a bitter storme of foule aduersity.
With foule dishonour him mote blot therefore;
Were yrkesome to report; yet that foule Beast
And Altars fouled, and blasphemy spoke,
Like as the fouler on his guilefull pype
For beasts and foules to feede vpon for their repast.
That is the greatest shame and foulest scorne,
That art thus foully fled from famous enemie?
To proue he liued ill, that did thus foully dye.
And thousand Sar'zins foully donne to dye.
Much like in foulnesse and deformity
He askt, who had that Dame so fouly dight;
Whereas so many knights had fouly bene fordonne.
Of all things to dissemble fouly may befall.
Them fouly rent, and shamefully defaced had.
And fouly rayle, with all she could inuent;
And traynes hauing surpriz'd, he fouly did to die.
Weening their wonted entrance to haue found
Hauing both found a new friend you to aid,
Then turning to his Lady, dead with feare her found.
Her seeming dead he found with feigned feare,
Till that at length she found the troden gras,
She found them both in darkesome corner pent;
Where noblest knights were to be found on earth:
Such ioy made Vna, when her knight she found;
Whom when she found, as she him left in plight,
Where when she came, she found the Faery knight
Where he vnwares the fairest Vna found,
And was possessed of his new found make.
If lesse, then that I feare, more fauour I haue found.
Found neuer helpe, who neuer would his hurts impart.
Whose gates he found fast shut, ne liuing wight
But that the knight him at auantage found,
There all within full rich arayd he found,
That fast was lockt, but key found not at all
He found the meanes that Prisoner vp to reare;
Where store they found of all, that dainty was and rare.
Me hither brought by wayes yet neuer found,
Or vnawares at disauantage found;
When I awoke, and found her place deuoyd,
O happy Queene of Faeries, that hast found
She found her selfe assayld with great perplexitie.
The many fauours I with thee haue found,
And found no place his deadly point to rest.
The yielding aire, which nigh too feeble found
But his late wounded wing vnseruiceable found.
In all the world like was not to be found,
There did I find, or rather I was found
The Amazon huge riuer now found trew?
Where may that treachour then (said he) be found,
Her late forlorne and naked he had found,
Him so I sought, and so at last I found
And goodly gorgeous barbes, him found not theare.
Might not be found a franker franion,
That may this day in all the world be found:
And eke of surest steele, that may be found,
Throughout the world, wher so they might be found,
And will be found with perill and with paine;
Long I her seru'd, and found her faithfull still,
At last such grace I found, and meanes I wrought,
There Atin found Cymochles soiourning,
There he him found all carelesly displayd,
And all the way, the wanton Damzell found
And smelling sweet, but there it might be found
Where drenched deepe he found in that dull ford
So long he yode, yet no aduenture found,
Whereas he sitting found in secret shade
Found no defect in his Creatours grace,
With Sacriledge to dig. Therein he found
Through that thicke couert he him led, and found
And found no place, where safe he shroud him might,
Ne euer could within one place be found,
But sith thou hast found fauour in mine eye,
By further search had passage found elsewhere,
There the good Guyon he found slumbring fast
Your selfe his prowesse prou'd & found him fiers & bold.
Fast flying, there eternall torment found,
They found the gates fast barred long ere night,
With greater fury, then before was found;
Diuerse delights they found them selues to please;
But not on ground mote like to this be found,
Whom he at sea found wandring from their wayes,
Which for this Realme found many goodly layes,
Ne had they footing found at last perdie,
In captiue bandes, which there they readie found:
He found himselfe dishonored so sore.
Yet tract of liuing creatures none they found,
Whom they found sitting on a sumptuous bed,
Where now on earth, or how he may be found;
Was neuer such, but mote the like be found,
That of no liuing wight he mote be found,
First entering, the dreadfull Mage there found
And cruddy bloud enwallowed they found
She found, and brought it to her patient deare
Whylome to haunt, but there she found him not;
But many there she found, which sore accused
Whereas she found the Goddesse with her crew,
Admyrd her goodly haueour, and found
There in a gloomy hollow glen she found
Where sitting on the flore the Hag she found,
He comming home at vndertime, there found
So safetie found at sea, which she found not at land.
So safetie found at sea, which she found not at land.
From her in flight, he found, that did him sore apall.
And found such fauour in their louing hartes,
Till I so many other Dames had found,
All, that I euer found so wisely stayd;
Whom I in countrey cottage found by chaunce;
Safe her, I neuer any woman found,
He found him not; for he had broke his band,
I found her golden girdle cast astray,
He came, which full of guests he found whyleare,
Hath found another partner of your payne:
Ere rest he found. Much there he suffered,
The Troian Brute did first that Citie found,
And great adue[n]tures found, that now were lo[n]g to sayne.
Found it the fittest soyle for their abode,
He found, then his false engins fast he plyde,
But soone he shall be found, and shortly doen be ded.
Where when he found it not (for Trompart bace
That at the last he found a caue with entrance small.
Whereas no gate they found, them to withhold,
To enter in, but found it locked fast:
For many labours more, then I haue found,
She found, and all their glory quite decayd,
Those dreadfull flames she also found delayd,
She found: for now that fained dreadfull flame,
Neither of them she found where she them lore:
There on the cold earth him now thrown she found,
Now freely drew, and found right safe assurance theare.
Yet many waies to enter may be found,
And made full goodly ioyance to her new found mate.
And of them all she that is fayrest found,
Though now their acts be no where to be found,
There she them found, all sitting round about
Them found all three according to their kynd:
Haue by good fortune found some beasts fresh spoyle,
And sure had it not happily found rest
That since their days such louers were not found elswhere.
Where they before them found in fresh aray
And as it fell, his steed he ready found.
That doubly did him grieue, when so himselfe he found.
There Satyrane Lord of the field he found,
In vaine he sought; for there he found it not;
There he in troupe found all that warlike crew,
There entring in, they found the goodman selfe,
And found himselfe on ground in great amazement.
That all his gealous feare he false had found,
I found her not, where I her left whyleare,
Fit time for him thence to depart it found,
But her therewith full sore displeasd he found,
And by the way she sundry purpose found
Yet found they none. But by what haplesse fate,
What glorie, or what guerdon hast thou found
Then when she lookt about, and nothing found
There was I found, contrary to my thought,
Where nought but darkesome drerinesse she found,
There she him found by that new louely mate,
Yet found no ease of griefe, nor hope of grace,
Arriuing there, he found this wretched man,
Amongst the rest a iewell rich he found,
There found she her (as then it did betide)
Of food, which in her duresse she had found:
And entring in, found none therein abide,
Yet found no fault, but that the Hag did scold
So furiously, that ere he wist, he found
But him the more agreeu'd I found thereby:
Thenceforth I found more fauour at her hand,
And made it so to ride, as it aliue was found.
In which he found great store of hoorded threasure,
For euery dram of hony therein found,
The which I found sure lockt and chained fast.
Which fuming all with frankensence I found,
This Gyant found her, and by force deflowr'd:
Her to redresse: but since he meanes found none
But all in vaine: for why he found no way
Of force, ne fraud in wight was to be found:
Vpon a day she found this gentle childe,
Mongst wicked men, in whom no truth she found,
He found him selfe, vnwist, so ill bestad,
How she was found againe, and spousde to Marinell.
At length found out, whereas she hidden lay
And mongst them al no change hath yet beene found.
For there is nothing lost, that may be found, if sought.
Whom when so lewdly minded Talus found,
And readie to deserue, what grace I found.
But none she found so fit to serue that turne,
Yet found no place, that could her liking please,
Yet found no easement in her troubled wits,
Whereas the Priestes she found full busily
Nath'lesse that stroke so cruell passage found,
But by aduenture found them faring so,
That hunting after game hath carrion found,
Oft making offer him to smite, but found
That she of death was guiltie found by right,
There he her found in sorrow and dismay,
Into his shield it readie passage found,
Long sought the Prince, but when he found no more
How that the Lady Belge now had found
Whiles she alone is left, and thou here found?
Her halfe dismayd they found in doubtfull plight,
And witnesse be Gerioneo found,
Tho when they came to the sea coast, they found
Whereas they readie found them to repell,
Ne euer any found his match in might;
That vertue should be plentifully found,
Ne was there Knight, ne was there Lady found
When as by chaunce a comely Squire he found,
There he that knight found lying on the flore,
(Whom Tristram slew) them in that shadow found,
So hauing both found fit occasion,
There he him found much better then he was,
Came to the place, where he his Lady found
But comming to the riuers side, he found
There he this most discourteous crauen found,
There he that knight full sorely bleeding found
But that same Ladies hurts no herbe he found,
Made in his tender flesh, but whole them all he found.
Found nothing that he said, vnmeet nor geason,
The Blatant Beast the fittest meanes they found,
Of this wyld man, whom they full busie found
Who whether he aliue be to be found,
He found that they had festred priuily,
He found the gate wyde ope, and in he rode,
There he him found enuironed about
There he him found in great astonishment,
Thence passing forth, not farre away he found,
Then found he many missing of his crew,
Serena, found of Saluages,
But when approching neare, he plainely found,
Found her by fortune, which to him befell,
For so great kindnesse as he found that day,
There he a troupe of Ladies dauncing found
She found no meanes to barre him, but to faine
Their Captaine there they cruelly found kild,
They found that life did yet in her remaine:
And turne we backe to Calidore, where we him found.
Ne wight he found, to whom he might complaine,
Ne wight he found, of whom he might inquire;
And feed an hundred flocks, there now not one he found.
At length when they occasion fittest found,
When to the Caue they came, they found it fast:
When he her found, but like to one distraught,
Mongst which he found a sword of better say,
Came to the place, where when he wrapped found
She found at last by very certaine signes,
Through all estates he found that he had past,
Where he him fou[n]d despoyling all with maine & might.
At last when as he found his force to shrincke,
Did on so weake foundation euer sit:
And her foundation forst, and feebled quight,
Whose false foundation waues haue washt away,
Cleopolis foundation first of all:
On firme foundation of true bountihed;
Euen from the sole of his foundation,
The worlds foundations from his centre fixt;
Albe Charissa were their chiefest founderesse.
There also some most famous founders were
Whether through foundring or through sodein feare
How many foundst thou such to put in thy record?
Yet dropping fresh out of the Indian fount,
Which from a sacred fountaine welled forth alway.
Foreby a fountaine, where I late him left
In secret shadow by a fountaine side:
To rest him selfe, foreby a fountaine side,
About the fountaine like a girlond made;
Through that fraile fountaine, which him feeble made,
Beside a bubbling fountaine low she lay,
In euery fountaine, and in euery lake,
Here is the fountaine of the worldes good:
She is the fountaine of your modestee;
And in the midst of all, a fountaine stood,
Out of this fountaine, sweet and faire to see,
That seemd the fountaine in that sea did sayle vpright.
Or bathe him in a fountaine by some couert glade.
Who hauing vewed in a fountaine shere
In a fresh fountaine, farre from all mens vew,
Sitting beside a fountaine in a rew,
Which as a fountaine from her sweet lips went,
That she at last came to a fountaine sheare,
Fountaines of gold and siluer to abound,
The which in floods and fountaines doe appere,
He has them now foure yeres besiegd to make the[m] thrall.
Is not enough foure quarters of a man,
Whom Romane warres, which now foure hundred yeares,
For twise foure hundreth yeares shalbe supplide,
And foure, since Florimell the Court for-went,
Which foure great Hippodames did draw in temewise tyde.
But foure of them the battell best beseemed,
Those foure were they, from whom false Florimell
So diuersly these foure disposed were to loue.
From all foure parts of heauen doe rage full sore,
Foure charged two, and two surcharged one;
Foure times his place he shifted hath in sight,
And euery body two, and two she foure did read.
From his infernall fournace forth he threw
For since the terme of fourteene hundred fyeres,
Such one was Auarice, the fourth of this faire band.
The fourth appointed by his office was,
And that fourth band, which cruell battry bent,
Against the fourth Bulwarke, that is the Tast,
The fourth was by that other knight dismayd,
From the fourth houre of night vntill the sixt;
[here, in 1609, 'The end of the Fourth Booke.']
The fourth Ecastor, of exceeding might;
But that fourth Mayd, which there amidst the[m] traced,
